And third, because, the Trinity being once acknowledged‚ it is proper that it should have her as a temple in which to dwell.l Therefore Augustino, as above [Enchiridi0n, 41] concludes: “That God dwells in his temple—not only the Holy Spirst, but the Father likewise‚ and also the Son. And of his body —by virtue of which he is made head of the church of God which is among men, in order that in all things he might have the pre-eminence——the Son said: ‘Destroy this temple and in three days I will build it up again' '' [John 2 : 21]. From these words of Augustine we deduce (Ι) that the universal church is one, praising God from the beginning of the world to the end; (2) that the holy angels are a part of the holy catholic church3 (3) that the part of the church called pilgrim or militant is helped by the church triumphant3 (4) that the church trium- phant and the church militant are bound together by the bond of love; (5) that the whole church and every part of it are to worship God, and that neither she nor any part of it wishes to be worshipped as God.
